pull_request.title: Logging Part 2: Inserting messages into a log file

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 2: Inserting messages into a log file

content.raw:
Oh, I just realized that `*db` (which is a `raii_sqlite3::Database`) has an `operator bool()`. However, this is calling the `operator bool()` of the `std::shared_ptr` which is containing the `raii_sqlite3::Database`.

If it's possible to have a situation where a `Database` has been allocated but is not valid, then we might actually want to do:

```
return this->dataPtr && this->dataPtr->db && *(this->dataPtr->db);
```

That should give us the intended behavior, if I understand correctly.
content.html:
Oh, I just realized that *db (which is a raii_sqlite3::Database) has an operator bool(). However, this is calling the operator bool() of the std::shared_ptr which is containing the raii_sqlite3::Database.

If it's possible to have a situation where a Database has been allocated but is not valid, then we might actually want to do:

return this->dataPtr && this->dataPtr->db && *(this->dataPtr->db);

That should give us the intended behavior, if I understand correctly.

pull_request.title: Logging Part 2: Inserting messages into a log file

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 2: Inserting messages into a log file

content.raw:
Was there any particular motivation for explicitly calling the implicit conversion operator here? It seems to work just fine by doing

```
return this->dataPtr && this->dataPtr->db;
```
content.html:
Was there any particular motivation for explicitly calling the implicit conversion operator here? It seems to work just fine by doing

return this->dataPtr && this->dataPtr->db;

pull_request.title: Logging Part 2: Inserting messages into a log file

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 2: Inserting messages into a log file

content.raw:
Yeah, I really like `Console`. I'd love to get a header-only implementation of it into the upcoming `ign-cmake` utilities, although it may be a bit tricky to make it header-only due to the static variables.

I think testing on actual files might have some value to it, although if we can rely on `sqlite3` to work equivalently on both types of databases (which I should hope is the case), then that alternative in-memory approach seems like a reasonable option.
content.html:
Yeah, I really like Console. I'd love to get a header-only implementation of it into the upcoming ign-cmake utilities, although it may be a bit tricky to make it header-only due to the static variables.

I think testing on actual files might have some value to it, although if we can rely on sqlite3 to work equivalently on both types of databases (which I should hope is the case), then that alternative in-memory approach seems like a reasonable option.

pull_request.title: Logging Part 2: Inserting messages into a log file

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 2: Inserting messages into a log file

content.raw:
Time would be pretty easy to replace with `std::chrono::nanoseconds`. I think the way the tests are using `Filesystem` could be replaced using the technique in the second section on [this page of the sqlite3 docs](https://www.sqlite.org/inmemorydb.html).

`Console` verbosity was very helpful while writing command line part. It would be  a shame to lose it, but we could make do with `std::cout` and `std::cerr`.
content.html:
Time would be pretty easy to replace with std::chrono::nanoseconds. I think the way the tests are using Filesystem could be replaced using the technique in the second section on this page of the sqlite3 docs.

Console verbosity was very helpful while writing command line part. It would be a shame to lose it, but we could make do with std::cout and std::cerr.

pull_request.title: Logging Part 2: Inserting messages into a log file

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 2: Inserting messages into a log file

content.raw:
Hypothetically, we could replace `Time` and `Console` with STL alternatives and then have the few integration tests depend on `ign-common` so they can use Filesystem (we would skip those tests if `ign-common` is unavailable).

I'm not saying this is a good idea, but it's an option, depending on how badly we want to minimize the dependency on `ign-common`.
content.html:
Hypothetically, we could replace Time and Console with STL alternatives and then have the few integration tests depend on ign-common so they can use Filesystem (we would skip those tests if ign-common is unavailable).

I'm not saying this is a good idea, but it's an option, depending on how badly we want to minimize the dependency on ign-common.

pull_request.title: Logging Part 2: Inserting messages into a log file

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 2: Inserting messages into a log file

content.raw:
We still haven't componentized `ignition-common`, so we're stuck with it being all-or-nothing for right now. Once it's broken into components, we would only need the core part of the library.

While I like the `Time` and `Console` classes, I'm pretty sure we can get by with basic STL functionality (but @sloretz can feel free to correct me if I'm wrong).

I think we should at least make `ignition-common1` an optional dependency instead of required, like I mentioned [here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/pull-requests/270/logging-part-2-inserting-messages-into-a/activity#comment-55613137).
content.html:
We still haven't componentized ignition-common, so we're stuck with it being all-or-nothing for right now. Once it's broken into components, we would only need the core part of the library.

While I like the Time and Console classes, I'm pretty sure we can get by with basic STL functionality (but @sloretz can feel free to correct me if I'm wrong).

I think we should at least make ignition-common1 an optional dependency instead of required, like I mentioned here.

content.raw: This dependency is not trivial as it is right now. I see that we're using `Time` and `Console`. Are these the only classes that we'll need for logging/playback? Are there any plans to depend only on the core part of Ignition Common?
content.html: This dependency is not trivial as it is right now. I see that we're using Time and Console. Are these the only classes that we'll need for logging/playback? Are there any plans to depend only on the core part of Ignition Common?

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 2: Inserting messages into a log file

content.raw:
Not that it matters for the test, but for anyone who might not know, you could use

```
const auto& topicMap = desc.TopicsToMsgTypesToId();
```

to avoid recreating a whole map.

Even though the return type of the function is a const-reference, if you use just plain `auto` the type will default to a non-const lvalue instead of a const-reference.
content.html:
Not that it matters for the test, but for anyone who might not know, you could use

const auto& topicMap = desc.TopicsToMsgTypesToId();

to avoid recreating a whole map.

Even though the return type of the function is a const-reference, if you use just plain auto the type will default to a non-const lvalue instead of a const-reference.

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 2: Inserting messages into a log file

content.html:
@sloretz We removed Descriptor::QueryMsgTypesOfTopic(), so this is no longer being used (and neither is QueryMsgTypesOfTopic()).

Should we just remove these unused functions? We could keep them around in case we ever want to bring back Descriptor::QueryMsgTypesOfTopic(), but that might be kind of pointless.

I'm mostly indifferent, but leaning towards removing these.
